utterances.utterance: What is transpiring right now should have never happened and it was an ill on Americans for decades to come.

utterances.speaker: REP. SETH MOULTON (D-MA)
utterances.utterance: All the scenes of total chaos that we saw play out on the T.V. yesterday could have been avoided if the administration had planned for this in advance.

utterances.speaker: SEN. MITHC MCCONNELL (R-KY)
utterances.utterance: What we have seen is an unmitigated disaster. A stain on the reputation of the United States of America.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right, Jesse, you are back. Let's turn it over to you to get some thoughts. Do you have some?

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.utterance: I wanted to get out of Afghanistan, but not like that, Dana. Imagine having 20 years to plan for something and this is the result. Jesse, Jr. could have planned a better exit strategy. In fact, Greg, he peered over his crib on Sunday and said, dad, why wouldn't President Biden leave in some air support in order to buy time for the evac? I said, it's a great question. I don't know. We're sitting on Sunday watching these images of people clinging from airplanes. The Taliban parading around with our weaponry and ISIS jail breaking, Americans surrounded. Joe Biden says, you know, we planned for this. Really? I'd like to see what winging it would look like, Joe. He said it's not my fault. Don't look at me. Really? He is the one that set the 9-11 pullout deadline with no conditions. Taliban heard that, they started advancing everywhere. He was getting intel briefings in June. He was getting them in July. He was getting them in August that showed the Taliban advancement. What did Joe do? Nothing. He actually went out on television after getting those briefings and said this wasn't going to happen. So Joe was slow, Joe lied, and then he remained on vacation. You can only hide incompetence for so long. Joe has done a good job of it. He hid when he was in the Senate. He hid as V.P. He hid during the campaign. COVID let him hide. But now it's the Joe show. It's only him in charge. And right as that happens, it all blows up. He killed the Afghan exit, killed the border, killed vaccine confidence with the J&J pause. We should have seen it coming. The guy botched the Iraq exit. The guy stranded Americans in Benghazi. This was the man that was supposed to be an experienced Washington hand. He knew how to pull the levers of power. Listen to his intelligence advisers. Make sure we have strong alliances. And in one weekend, that's just shattered. I don't trust him anymore. Who's going to trust this guy? Oh, Joe's going to crack down on illegal gun trafficking in America. Just arm the Taliban. Oh, Joe, you're going to ask for billions for the Green New Deal. Really? How did the billions work out training the Afghan army? That's how it's going to go now and I'm sorry, this is going to haunt Joe Biden for the rest of his short presidency.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I also -- rarely can be shocked, but I actually was by this question and answer, Geraldo. Let's get your take on this. Because he was just in Europe in June and remember America is back. Here's what Jake Sullivan said.

utterances.speaker: SULLIVAN
utterances.utterance: He has not yet spoken with any other world leaders. Myself, Secretary Blinken, several other senior members of the team, have been engaged on a regular basis with foreign counterparts, and we intend to do so in the coming days.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Now, do you remember, Geraldo, how mad the foreign policy establishment was and Democrats were about how President Trump was mean to NATO because he asked them to pay their fair share. And this -- actually, Article V, this is the only time Afghanistan has ever been invoked, and our allies are there -- the Australian reporter, she was like, do you realize how mad people are, that people are trapped behind enemy lines and you're leaving them there? Get your thoughts.

utterances.speaker: GERALDO RIVERA, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.utterance: It's like they are all stoned and hiding. I don't get the absolute utter incompetence. Like most Americans, I wanted out of Afghanistan, but this reckless, irresponsible, incompetent execution of the non-plan is absolutely appalling to me. And it's such a rookie mistake and when you think about Afghanistan where I've spent a lot of time between 2001 and 2012, 11 assignments there. To think that you have Bagram Airbase, a wonderful impenetrable, formidable fortress of an airbase that can land any aircraft of any size, and instead of Bagram, which you give back to the enemy, you keep the Kabul airport, which is in a big depression. It's a bowl. It's a horrible place. Not defensible at all. It just shows how absolutely incompetent they were and the United States embassy. The United States embassy, I was in the United States embassy when there was a mortar attack on the embassy. I was with Ryan Crocker. Nobody got hurt. The buildings are this thick. Again, it is a place where you could have an orderly withdrawal. Instead, you have kids like these, these preppy, you know, self-important, just Ivy asses that just were unconnected to the reality. And just the -- I hasten to add the one thing we can never forget is the service and sacrifice of our G.I.'s in that awful place for 20 years. Honor their service, remember everything they have sacrificed, they and their families, and don't let the incompetence and absolute bungling of this affect their legacy and the honor we pay them.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I agree, Geraldo. Let's just not bring preppy into this.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Okay. Sorry.

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.utterance: I think the, you know, I think the word you are looking for was mediocrities. When you look at the -- we -- we believe when we look at our leaders, we think it's different than our lives. That it somehow -- oh, it somehow changes. Everything changes in that stratosphere. Wherever you go in life, wherever you work, you're going to have mediocrities, incompetence. This is proof. And this is the only thing you can defend Joe Biden on, and I'm not going to do it. But that it if -- 20 years, they had 20 years to plan this. So, it's just not entirely on him, right? I mean, a few extra months of planning wouldn't do a lick of difference if you had 20 years. Having said that, that's still no defense for him, right. This guy is damaged goods. He -- I don't see --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: You're talking about the preppy guy or the president?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The president. I think --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I don't think that you can blame the staff necessarily.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think that this was, I mean, they might be able to say that the staff wasn't good, but the president made the decision.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. That's what I'm saying. I'm talking about the 20 years of incompetence and corruption, that there is a whole bunch of people involved in there, but he is holding the bag here. And the reason why, and this is the biggest reason why. Who was the leader who said the number one threat to America was not the Taliban, not ISIS, not AL Qaeda, but white supremacy, Trump voters. So, F him. He overestimated the white rube and underestimated the terrorists. He underestimated the Taliban. We forget, as Jesse points out, that he is wrong on everything. He didn't even want to go after Bin Laden. So this is a consequence of his manufacturing of fear to somehow get back at a segment of the population under the lie of being a unifier. Again, par for the course, to your point, every choice that he has made is to undermine order. The southern border, no process. Law and order, defund and say you didn't -- ignoring crime. Afghanistan, ripped the band-aid off because that's the only way you can do it. Every decision results in absolute disorder. How can they come back to this? The y should be -- there should be resignations. And by the way, this is why they're keeping Kamala out of this because they know he's done. He's toast.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Can I add the energy police to that?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: In terms (inaudible), I think that is leading to some of these problems as well. Last word to you Kennedy.

utterances.speaker: LISA KENNEDY MONTGOMERY, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.utterance: Yes. Throw the door open in Western Europe for Russia, but shut down our energy policy here.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: The surprise from the administration, whether it's Antony Blinken or the president or, you know, any number of advisers, like, man, we just did not see this coming. This happened so quickly. And it's like -- if you've ever known someone who's dated a crazy person and they just kept dating them and dating them because they were so scared to break up with them, it's like that. But the guy decided to break up with her at a baseball game during the World Series on the kiss cam.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: That was like, you know, the worst possible engineering of something that was --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: That's a vivid, vivid analogy.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: It was already going to go bad in the first place. And to your point, like, let's give them some credit. Let's say for 10 years people thought this might work out.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: But in your 10, then you have 10 years to figure out how to get out and you didn't listen to one person who had been there. One person who had studied this for their life's work, the academics and the military academies. You did not listen to anyone because they were all Cassandra and they all foretold what is happening right now, which could have dire consequences and sink this administration.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I would also add, which is one of the comment on this, is that I believe that you'll see the intelligence community, as they are very good at doing, we've seen it for years, and they do it to all the presidents. Like, if their credibility has come into question here -- remember, they were the ones who were leaking to the media that they were telling them that this was a possibility. So you'll probably see more of that. And even Senator Menendez, New Jersey Democrat, said there's got to be accountability and hearings on that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Do you think this is worse than Watergate?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Oh, everything.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Literally everything. In fact, your new part of your hair is worse than Watergate.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Is something wrong with my hair?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, I think its back. I think its back now.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, okay.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: When you part it on the other side, the thing -- the thing, yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, I put it back -- I parted it --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Everything -- I feel much more --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: By the way, we're worried about the Taliban. There is an axe wielding maniac downtown in New York that just hack some dude up at an ATM. We have serious problems here. We have major problems here.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Yes, introduce terrorism into that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: True.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Much more to come including new fears of Al Qaeda 3.0 as experts warn of the potential for another 9/11.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Following President Biden's catastrophic withdrawal and the Taliban's victory in Afghanistan, America may be facing an elevated terror threat here at home from groups like Al-Qaeda. Remember Al-Qaeda? In just 25 days we will be commemorating the 20th anniversary of the horrible 9/11 attacks that took so many American lives. And now, top Pentagon officials and others are warning that terrorist back in or rather, based in Taliban-controlled Afghanistan could launch new attacks here on the U.S. homeland. Now, given that nightmare scenario, Republican lawmakers now slamming President Biden and accusing him of putting American lives at risk.

utterances.speaker: REP. MICHAEL WALTZ (R-FL)
utterances.utterance: The biggest thing, Sean, it's a disaster for our counterterrorism. America is less safe. Al-Qaeda 3.0 will come roaring back. Al-Qaeda and the Taliban are absolutely married at the hip. But this time when we go back in, the Taliban are going to be better armed with taxpayer funded equipment. We have no basis in the region and we have no local allies because they've all been hunted down. I want to see resignations.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I want to see resignations also, Greg, but I have a slightly different take on it. Remember what happened the last time the Taliban hosted Al-Qaeda? Al-Qaeda hit us. So, we came back. We wiped out the Taliban and we took their country.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: In other words, their support of Al-Qaeda cost them their country for 20 years. Why would they be so eager now that they have their country back to sponsor Al-Qaeda?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But they already are. Sorry.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, I mean, it's also -- there might be --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: You're next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- there is a silver lining. Once ISIS sees land, they had to keep it. And once you start keeping land, you become a target. You can't be underground forever. So, if the Taliban starts doing some really, really heinous crap, we can -- they're going to have to be public about it. And if Al-Qaeda comes out, we have to create a way -- I call it, you know, the pest-control analogy, terror control. But I am happy that Admiral -- what, Milley? Is that his name? He moved up the terror threat. It is now more dangerous than a white Republican, but still not as lethal as a Trump voter. You got to remember, the war on terror was supposed to shift to white supremacy. So this has got to chafe on Lemon's butt, because they're not -- CNN's not going to be able to pull this anymore because now you got to deal with the Taliban. I'm just hoping that if the Taliban creates a government, it is easier to annihilate them if we choose because they are now not hiding in tunnels.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: As long as they don't bring white supremacist.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. Exactly. They could be white supremacists.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: But, Dana, you disagree with the analysis that why support Al- Qaeda when Al-Qaeda is so hot.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think -- well, I don't disagree that that would make logical sense. The problem is Al-Qaeda has already pledged to be there. And the Taliban has been working with them and the U.N. report just recently said that. So, I think that's the facts of the ground already or that it's not just Al-Qaeda, but every other sort of radical Islamic terrorism group now. Even if they don't come to Afghanistan, that might be where the Taliban get smart, right? Maybe they say, well, don't come here. We'll help you there.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They don't get along, do they? There are like 20 of them, right? Twenty different groups.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: There are factions I know (ph).

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: (Inaudible).

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think, though, that --.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: They're in a (inaudible)?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. They're in the (inaudible).

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think the most important thing of the last 20 years has been -- we didn't start the war. Remember, the war came to us and then we decided to go on the offense, and that has to remain. So, this helps remind everybody that you can't get in to September 10th thinking and complacency then that won't be a bad thing. Remember the 3:00 a.m. phone call ad on 2016? We didn't talk too much about that in 2020, but we probably should have.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: So what do you think about Al-Qaeda?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: And the legitimacy of this group that was basically defunct coming back to life because of the Taliban.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, I think the immediate threat now are the Americans that are still in Afghanistan. And if one of those Americans or one of our allies dies at the hands of the Taliban Joe thinks things bad or bad now after that happens, it's going to be like an Iran hostage situation. Also, these refugees, some of them deserve to have amnesty and to come here. Do I trust Joe Biden to vet them? Of course I don't. It does not look like good vetting is going on at the Kabul airport right now, Geraldo.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: But don't you --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And to think that the guy who let the Boston bombers come in here after Russia said hey, watch out for these guys --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: They came in as children.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They were alerted by Moscow to this administration and we didn't do anything because there was this misspelling. They also let the San Bernardino shooter in here after his social media was plastered --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: He was born here, but his wife came from Russia.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- plastered with jihadist propaganda, Geraldo. I don't trust Joe to vet. He's incompetent. So that's a threat to the homeland, too. Great question today at the briefing to Jake Sullivan, woman don't know her name, had a mask on. She said, what about the NATO allies? What about Taiwan? What about South Korea? Are we going to defend them after what we just witnessed and a propaganda gift to Russia, China, North Korea. They're just going to tell those targets, do you think the Americans are competent enough to save your butt. It's going to hurt.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: There's a big difference between Taiwan and South Korea and Afghanistan. Afghanistan's in the middle of nowhere. Do you -- what was your first feeling when you saw the crowds at the airport yesterday and Sunday?

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Just that it was it was a horrible visual that is going to stick to this presidency. That is one of those things that -- and you know, you can always tell when something is repeated by people you agree with and disagree with on social media, when it has like that kind of reverberation because so many people they think in pictures, you know, and that's what they latch on to. And I think, you know, in terms of terror, I hope to god that there's not a terror attack here.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: But I think we've grown so complacent and we have given over so many of our civil liberties during the pandemic that, you know, we could have a massive compromise if there's a terror attack here. And to your point, I don't trust anyone in the federal government to do any kind of vetting because they have shown their failure over and over and over again. Though, the one Greg was talking about, silver linings, I think cops will come out better from this because they have been so demonized during the pandemic --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: -- that now when you see NYPD officers with the counter- terrorism badge on their uniforms --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: That's a good point.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: -- people go, okay, good. Someone's here whose actually going to pay attention to stuff and they're going to keep me safe so.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: There you go.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Just one last note about this. My translator for many years in Afghanistan is hiding out in Kabul hoping to get one of those rides through the Taliban roadblocks to the airport. Many international groups are working to get that to make that happen, but it's something that is extremely concerning to many of us. Straight ahead, where is Kamala, the vice president who boasted of her role in removing U.S. troops from Afghanistan now silent?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Kamala Harris mostly silent after bragging about her role in helping shape Joe Biden's disastrous Afghanistan withdrawal.

utterances.speaker: DANA BASH, CNN CHIEF POLITICAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.utterance: He just made a really big decision, Afghanistan.

utterances.speaker: KAMAL HARRIS, VICE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.utterance: Were you the last person in the room?

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.utterance: And you feel comfortable?

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.utterance: I do. He is someone who I have seen over and over again make decisions based on what he truly believes based on his years of doing this work and studying these issues, what he truly believes is the right thing to do.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That did not age well. And it's only a couple of days old. Kamala did manage to tweet, "For two decades, our courageous servicemembers put their lives on the line in Afghanistan. We will always be grateful and proud. Ending U.S. military involvement in Afghanistan is the right decision." Kennedy, is that kind of a straw -- the straw man argument? No one -- you know, it's a convincing argument to leave Afghanistan. That's how -- no one's upset about that. It's how it was done, how botched it was.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Yes. That's like everyone agrees that we should free Britney.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: No one thinks that we should push her data off a bridge.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: There is a very big difference. She is wrong on everything. And, you know, she is so narcissistic. And why didn't she take the call from Joe and go down and, to Dana's point, and start calling foreign leaders? You know, she is the vice president of the United States and she is certainly not taking a leadership role here, which is also no surprise.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. All right, Dana, what's really going on? What's going on behind the scenes?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I don't know. I feel like something is going on.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Something is up. I don't know what it is, but something -- I smell some kind of thing and it's not gas.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes. I'm glad you clarified it. Do you remember at the beginning of the administration, the -- I was going to call him the Prime Minister, Ron Klain the chief of staff, he -- they had Kamala Harris do all these world leader calls. Do you guys remember this?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, that was weird.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And she -- so, she was making relationships. She was building up a partnership with all these people. And then you -- at the briefing today, you find out that President Biden hasn't called anyone. We just found out in the commercial break that the White House has just alerted the world that after that briefing, where they said the President had not spoken to any other world leader for the last several days, he has now spoken to Boris Johnson of the U.K., so I'll take that for what it's worth. Also, I have to imagine that the women's groups and the human rights groups have to be thinking that they could have expected more from the first woman vice president --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Historical.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- to at least maybe say something.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: A woman of color no less. A woman of color first female VP, mom on the situation for Afghan women, Geraldo. How's your hero now?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Which one are you referring to? You know, I always go to Erica when I want to speak about a woman in the leadership role, because it's very easy to say, oh, they come off as nasty or they're overbearing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Erica Kane?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: You know, I think they -- my wife, Erica.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Yes, that's right, or my children, race reference.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: She was named after Erica Kane, and I kissed Erica Kane.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You mean, Susan Lucci?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Did she kissed you back.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: He gave her first Emmy.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Sorry, Susan.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: But I really think she's in a very tough spot. And I don't know how competent she is in this role. She was -- she was pretty good as a senator and a D.A. and an attorney general, but I'm not sure how good she is and it's a very difficult role. And Joe Biden was a great vice president. Kamala Harris so far has been pretty mediocre vice president.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You're being quite diplomatic. Jessie, could it be she's out of the picture to preserve her brand. Like she's like, don't get -- she doesn't want her fingerprints on this now. She's hide -- she's in hiding.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Maybe. Yes, unlike Geraldo, I don't consult my wife before I talk about women's issues on television.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Maybe you should.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Maybe I should. Maybe I should. But now, Kamala has become the laughingstock that Joe was when he was vice president. And so, she has three options because this is a loyalty test right now. Number one option, she could come out and she could be a good VP and say, you know what, it was Trump's fault. It was the Afghan army's fault. And she could really show Joe that she has his back. Number two, you leak. And you leak that, you know what, I had some questions about this execution and no one listened to me. Maybe it was a sexism thing. And you get that out there, kind of risky, or she just goes silent. She goes silent for about a month, and then she does a softball, and she gets the cameras to film her hugging Afghan women as they arrive at the tarmac here in the United States. That's her only option. She embraces that I saved your life, woman because I am a strong woman. And that's her play.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Now, once she does that, she'll have to credit you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, because she's watching. I know.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's why he put it out there.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And let's she wears a mask.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right, up next, vaccine mandates are officially here. You'll now need to show proof to do just about anything.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Some breaking news to tell you about. Texas Governor Greg Abbott announcing he's tested positive for COVID after being fully vaxxed. The governor says he's got no symptoms. And that happening as COVID mandates are officially here. New York City leading the way and other places aren't far behind in ordering many indoor businesses to check for proof of vaccinations before allowing people inside. Check out this list of things you can't do if you don't show proof that you got the shot. Now, keep in mind, only 33 percent of Black New Yorkers are vaccinated. Well, I mean, no one can read that in the audience, not because they're old, but because the script is very small. But Greg, you've seen this list. It's basically every time you go indoors, if you don't have the shot, they'll turn you right around.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. Two points here. Can you imagine the spectacle of a Black family going to a restaurant full of white people? They're told they have to sit outside. So, you've got -- you've got quite a quite a visual for the winter, right? White people in, Black people out, that's not going to go well, which leads to the next question, what's missing? The COVID cops? Is there a force that's going to be going around enforcing this stuff?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: There is.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Really?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: There is.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Because --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: 600 agents have been hired by De Blasio.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: They have big fines too.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Because remember, things like selling loosie cigarettes ended up in tragedy. Regulatory laws forcing police to become like little schoolmarm nurse ratchets ends up in tragedy. I think -- I think it's -- I think they should have -- they should all be De Blasio staff should be going around policing this.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, Geraldo, you're saying 600 COVID cops in a city of 8.5 million are going to enforce this?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: This sounds about as well-thought-through as the Afghan exit strategy.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: But remember, they're not checking the customers, they're checking the restaurants.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: The restaurants -- the restaurants have to comply, or if they don't comply, in other words, they don't check the customers, the first time is a $1,000 fine. The second offense is $2000.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But how do they prove that they've checked.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: They watch. They watch the restaurant. The guy comes in, they check them, they don't check them.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, it's on site.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's -- OK.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: It doesn't --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But do you remember how many people ended up having terrible situations at their places of business because they were asking people to wear masks because that was mandated? And to your point, there's not six -- there's not -- 600 is not enough.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: It's a start.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I'm vaccinated. I'm fine with it.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I get your ideology here but 900,000 new cases last week.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We can't --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: 900,000 new cases, that just the most since last January.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Here in New York City?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The statistics doesn't tell you what they are.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Nationwide, most since January.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Nationwide, not in New York City.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It doesn't tell you the age of the people, is it asymptomatic? Just saying there's new cases, it doesn't mean anything.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: But then -- see, the thing with you and race and about the shots, Black people being excluded from restaurants and so forth, the --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's a good point.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: We should urge the, you know, the icons of the community to urge their constituents to save their lives, to get well, to get the vaccination, rather than pointing out how horrible it would be to turn someone around, you know --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, and it's going to happen.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Kennedy.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: One of my neighbors who happens to be a doctor in the Bronx, that is his biggest frustration because he is begging members of communities of color to get the vaccine. And there's so much skepticism, you know, regardless of these reeducation programs that New York City and every other big city and every other state has been imposing on people. And he's so frustrated. He's like, where's LeBron James?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Right, right.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Like, why doesn't LeBron James --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Jay Z.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Because he would do so much more to convince --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He's too busy defending China who brought this here.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Yes, absolutely.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I mean, think about that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Good point. Yes.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: No, but in a lot of restaurants are saying like, no, we really like this because they're desperate for business.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Because their businesses have been just, you know, shellacked by 75 percent. And they're trying whatever they can to get people back in the door. And you know that there are going to be guys at the door going, yes, that's the vaccine, whatever. You know just making it seem like you're looking at phone.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And how convenient it is for the government to turn the private companies into the authoritarians so they don't have to deal with this climate.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: That's a good point.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They could just let the companies do it. Hey, it's private. You guys make your mind up. But it's not really making their mind up because you've got lawyers breathing down your neck.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Lawyers, God, I hate those lawyers. Up next --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Sorry.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Sorry, not you, Geraldo. Well, up next, liberals have a new solution to how to control violence, paying criminals to not commit crimes.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: New York City now paying people not to commit crimes -- what a country -- by offering a stipend of $1000 bucks a month to violent teens who stay out of trouble. Teens will also get mentoring from older ex-cons as part of the sweet deal. The program has been tested out in other cities, but with mixed results. So, Dana, can something like this actually work? I know they've tried it in a few cities in California but it really hasn't caught on.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I can imagine why. I mean, when I hear violent teen, I'm thinking OK, well then that's no. I don't want my taxpayer dollars to go to violent teen. I understand the desire to help put people on a better path. I also like the idea of the mentoring. I don't think that's bad. But I think just giving people more money and more reasons not to actually find the discipline and freedom that comes from working and the dignity that comes from working is a bad idea.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Well, Jesse, you have three kids so far. I was thinking about this --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So far.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: What time is it?

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: I was thinking about this and you know my oldest daughter -- of course, I want her to get a summer job, but now I'm looking at this. And I think she should go right up and just say I'm not a violent teen yet, but $1000 bucks a month, that would really keep me from being a violent teenager.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Here's a Ruger. Have a fun summer. So, I'm a taxpayer here in New York City. Some 17-year-old shoots me in the foot. I go to the hospital. I have to give this guy a shooting bonus, $1,000 to shoot Jesse. Not a bad idea.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: It's actually $1,000 not to shoot Jesse.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: You have to shoot first.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: If you shoot someone like Jesse, you get $1,000 a month.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think this is incentivizing violence.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think it's a good point.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: They've tried it out in other cities and like, for a year, homicides and gun violence goes down, but then it sort of creeps back up. That's why you know, it doesn't have the sort of long term traction. But if you look at the stories in New York City, and Chicago, and you know, young men are killing each other, they're just shooting each other in cold blood, so you have to do something, Geraldo. But is this really it?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: We had 16 shot here in two hours in New York City. In Chicago over the weekend, they were eight killed, and 53, 54 wounded, so you have to do something. I had a different idea a couple of years ago to pay fathers to stay with their families, because I believe -- yes, the long experience, that that's the key indicator of what the kid is going to do or what's going to happen to kids whether or not there's a dad in the home. But I'm willing to try anything with this kind of carnage. And I say, again, this is the civil rights issue of our time. It's the young Black men killing each other. If we don't stop that, we're going to lose a whole generation. It's happening. Nobody wants to talk about it. And it gets submerged by all the other obviously, huge stories. But this is the civil rights issue of our time. This is the story of the moment. And I'm all for any innovative idea that makes sense. If you're going to give a kid, he doesn't do anything bad for month, you give him $1000 --

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Well, what about -- what about giving a kid you know money when they do well in school or when they come up with --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Again, good.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: -- with an awesome science project.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Good, good, I'm all for it.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: I mean, I'd rather do that. I'd rather incentivize like --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But they're giving -- but they're getting rid of standards, so you don't even have to prove that you did well in school.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Oh my God, that's so true.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That really irks you, doesn't it, Dana?

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: It's awful. And they're getting rid of standards going back in the fall. So, they won't be able to test kids to see their learning deficits from the pandemic because it is an utter abject failure. But to Geraldo's point, you demonize legal gun owners, right? And you also, you demonize white supremacists and Trump voters and you never really get it. Kamala Harris's favorite thing, the root causes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. The reason why Geraldo is saying we -- I'm willing to try anything is because we threw out the thing that worked, which is prison. The new incentive is $1,000 because the old incentive is no longer there. It's like, well, we'll pay them not to commit crime because we're not imprisoning them for committing crimes. That's the scary part. So, now, we are forced to pay people to not to do things we expected human beings to do for free which is be a decent human being. Number two, we've also legalized extortion. De Blasio just instituted what we went after the mafia four, which is a protection racket. We are paying since criminals not to hurt us. That is OK.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I'm OK -- I'm OK with it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, because you're rich and you don't live in New York. I mean, I have a question.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I live in Cleveland, three people in one night.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, it's probably your fault, Geraldo.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I want to pay -- I want to pay those people not to do that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You probably mowed them down in your Rolls Royce or what have you been driving lately? No, it is -- it is really scary that this is what we've come to. I made your daughter's should apply for this, because if they don't give it to her, it's racist, number one.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Is it just only Black kids that are going to get this? What about your maniacal daughter?

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Is it only kids who have committed crimes? What about kids who might commit crimes?

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: I hope you're --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. What if you're thinking -- what if your daughter is thinking about committing a crime?

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Give me a grand and I won't do it.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: No, $500 if you're only thinking them.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: It probably blows through that new breeds in a weekend. "ONE MORE THING" is up next. Stay with us.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's time for "ONE MORE THING." Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, we're going to do a Juan Williams imitation here. I'm going to show you family photos of myself with the fam in Maine on vacation. There's everybody Sophie, Ellie, Solon, mom and dad. Eliza, Emma, there we are. Jesse Jr., I have him in a BabyBjorn. How cool do I look with a BabyBjorn? That's his first boat ride. My mom made us put a lifejacket on him. I don't think it fit. I think I might have cut off air to his head. But we survived the boat ride. And there he is. I almost dropped him off the ledge there.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: Oh, God.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But how beautiful do look? It's so cool.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Did you grew a beard?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I did grow a beard. Sophie and Ellie at the rocks, Pemaquid. And there it is. I did grow a beard.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: How was the lobster?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Lobster was delicious.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: My times did you eat lobster?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I only had it once.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I'm surprised.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Very prudent.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Very prudent. All right --

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: You mean fiscally or --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I don't know what I mean, Geraldo.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: We didn't have a special "ONE MORE THING" yesterday, so I brought mine back from yesterday. So, Saturday night, I didn't anticipate having so much fun. But I ended up having a great time at this concert. And the band was called -- is called Kirk and the Jerk. So, it's Brian Kirk and I got to have a little picture with him. They play at the Jersey Shore area, but I mean that they go other places as well. They're absolutely amazing. They can play any song. You name it, they can play it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's nice.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Also, happy anniversary to Peter. We met 24 years ago today on an airplane.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Congrats.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It can happen. You never know who --

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: And he liked your ponytail.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: He did like my ponytail.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Good thing you didn't have a mask on. He wouldn't have seen what you look like.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I mean, but he liked my ponytail. I don't know. But it's a great point. Greg, you're next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right, tonight, I have Rob O'Neill on the show. I wonder what we're going to talk about. He killed Bin Laden. And I got Charlie Hurt. I got Guy Benson, Kat. Let's do this.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Oh, wow. Great show.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, 11:00 p.m. Greg's Computer News. You know, I was driving around today around the city. You wouldn't believe who I saw just driving alone next to me. It was Robert De Niro. Do we have it here? He's right there. Maybe we don't. There he is. He's very -- he's very unhappy. He's got a lot of alimony scowling driving around. He was driving he a tempo. Remember the tempo?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I've never seen an arm out like that -- or a leg out like that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He was making a signal. He was doing -- yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes, he's like left.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Look at that. Look at that.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: I feel like he needs a cigarette.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, he does. And that is my "ONE MORE THING."

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I need a cigarette. Hey, America.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh my goodness.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Did you ever smoke?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Not one?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: She's lying.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I've never smoked pot and I'm proud of it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Never?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Only goes the edibles.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I never had an edible.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Greg has an edible right now.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, in my pocket.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I'm afraid to try it. OK, Geraldo.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They're fantastic.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: Here is Geraldo's Geraldo news with Geraldo. But this is the Sol Rivera edition. My wonderful, engaged, loving, compassionate daughter spoke at a group called Friendship Circle which is where the typical kids get paired up with the developmentally disabled kids, the handicapped kids, and they befriend them and they spend time with them. And Sol is such a loving person. Here she's addressing the crowd and saying, you know, I'm following in my dad's footsteps, which make me there's a Yiddish word Kvell. Speaking of which, there's my mother on Nancy, her husband, Jerry, and Erica on the left there, of course, and (INAUDIBLE). And there's the rabbi. There's Jewish thing that Phil only call -- anyway, it's a -- he's a -- he's a nice guy. But we raise -- we raised money for the Friendship Circle to, you know, some to make a donation to autism and so forth.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Awesome. That's awesome. She's great.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Great.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Kennedy.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: This one is for the moms because you guys have been boozing it up since the beginning of the pandemic. Day drinking is up for moms of young children by 323 percent. I think we can do better than that. I think we can get it up to 400 by the end of this year. Yesterday was National Rum Day and I want to give you a cocktail recipe, the Pineapple Sour. Two ounces of pineapple rum, an ounce of lime juice, and three and a half -- three quarters of an ounce, rather, of simple syrup. It's not too hard. Keep it simple, ladies.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: What makes it so simple? That's what I wanted to know.

utterances.speaker: MONTGOMERY
utterances.utterance: It's just sugar and water.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Oh, OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: There you go.

utterances.speaker: RIVERA
utterances.utterance: It's pretty simple.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I mean, that's pretty simple. There's nothing simple about the next show though. That's it for us. "SPECIAL REPORT" is up next. Hey, Bret.
